[[File:Prominenthill-flotation.jpg|thumb|Copper-sulfide-loaded air bubbles on a Jameson Cell at the flotation plant of the [[Prominent Hill]] mine in [[South Australia]]]] The '''Jameson Cell''' is a high-intensity [[froth flotation]] cell that was invented by Laureate Professor [[Graeme Jameson]] of the [[University of Newcastle (Australia)]] and developed in conjunction with [[Mount Isa Mines]] Limited ("MIM", a subsidiary of [[MIM Holdings Limited]] and now part of the [[Glencore]] group of companies).<ref name = "Jameson1991">G J Jameson, G Harbort and N Riches, "The development and application of the Jameson Cell," in: ''Fourth Mill Operators' Conference, Burnie, Tasmania, 10–14 March 1991'' (The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy: Melbourne, 1991), 45–50.</ref>
==Introduction== [[File:Jameson Cells pictured adjacent to flotation columns at the Mount Isa lead-zinc concentrator.png|thumbnail|Figure 1. Comparison of the sizes of conventional column flotation cells and Jameson Cells with similar capacities.]]
The high intensity of the Jameson Cell means that it is much shorter than conventional [[Froth flotation#Flotation equipment|column flotation cells]] (see Figure 1), and it does not require air compressors to aerate the suspension of ground ore particles and water (known as a ''[[slurry]]'' or ''pulp'') in the flotation cell.<ref name = "Jameson1992">G J Jameson, "Flotation cell development," in: ''The AusIMM Annual Conference, Broken Hill, New South Wales, 17–21 May 1992'' (The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy: Melbourne, 1992), 25–31.</ref> The lack of a requirement for compressed air and the lack of moving parts means that power consumption is less than for the equivalent mechanical or conventional column flotation cell.<ref name = "Young2013">M F Young, K E Barnes, G S Anderson and J D Pease, [http://www.jamesoncell.com/EN/Downloads/technical%20papers/Jameson%20Cell%20-%20%20The%20Comeback%20in%20Base%20Metal%20Applications%20Using%20Improved%20Design%20and%20Flow%20Sheets.pdf. "Jameson Cell: the ‘comeback' in base metals applications using improved design and flow sheets,"] in: ''Proceedings of the 38th Annual Canadian Mineral Processors Conference, Ottawa, Ontario, 17–19 January 2006'', (Canadian Institute of Mining, Metallurgy and Petroleum), 311–332. Accessed 23 May 2013.</ref>
In contrast to most types of [[Froth flotation#Flotation equipment|flotation cell]], the Cell introduces the feed and the air to the Cell in a combined stream via one or more cylindrical columns referred to as "downcomers". Other types of flotation cell typically introduce the feed and the air separately to the cell.<ref name = "Jameson1992"/>
The Cell produces fast mineral flotation rates, especially for very fine mineral particles.<ref name = "Young2013"/> It produces high concentrate grades from fast floating liberated particles <ref name = "Barns2009">K E Barns, P J Colbert and P D Munro, "Designing the optimal flotation circuit – the Prominent Hill case," in: ''Tenth Mill Operators' Conference, Adelaide, South Australia, 12–14 October 2009'' (The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy: Melbourne, 2009), 173–182.</ref> and is able to do this from a single stage of flotation.<ref name = "Barns2009"/> The high carrying capacity of the Jameson Cell is particularly beneficial when high yields (mass pulls) are required, such as in recleaning in metals flotation and in the flotation of metallurgical coal, where yields can exceed 80%.<ref name = "Araya">R Araya, L Huynh, M Young and K Arburo, "Solving challenges in copper cleaning circuits with the Jameson Cell," to be presented at: Procemin 2013,Santiago, Chile, 15–18 October 2013.</ref>
The Cell was initially developed as a lower-cost alternative to conventional column flotation cells for recovering fine particles, and was first used in the Mount Isa lead–zinc concentrator in 1988.<ref name = "Readett">D Readett and B Clayton, "Cleaning hydrometallurgical liquor using Jameson Cells," in: ''Flotation Plants – Are They Optimized?'' Ed. Deepak Malhotra (Society of Mining, Metallurgy and Exploration: Littleton, Colorado, 1993), 164–170. {{ISBN|0-87335-124-X}}.</ref> Since then, use of the technology has spread to include coal flotation, base and precious metal flotation, potash flotation, oil sands flotation, molybdenum flotation, graphite flotation and cleaning [[solvent extraction]] liquors.<ref name = "Installations">Xstrata Technology, [http://www.jamesoncell.com/EN/Installations/Documents/JamesonCellInstallations.pdf "Jameson Cell installations,"] Accessed 29 May 2013.</ref> Xstrata Technology, Glencore Xstrata's technology marketing arm, listed 328 Jameson Cell installations in May 2013.<ref name = "Installations"/> Cells have been installed by 94 companies in 27 countries.<ref name = "Installations"/> Today, the technology is the standard in the Australian Coal Industry<ref name = "Firth">B A Firth, "Australian coal flotation practice," in: ''Advances in Flotation Technology'' (The Society of Mining, Metallurgy and Exploration: Littelton, Colorado, 1999), 289–307. {{ISBN|0-87335-184-3}}.</ref> where well over one hundred Cells have been installed to recover coal fines.<ref name = "Applications">Xstrata Technology, [http://www.jamesoncell.com/EN/Applications/Pages/Applications.aspx "Jameson Cell Applications."] Accessed 1 July 2013.</ref><ref name = "Osborne">D Osborne, L Huynh, I Kohli, M Young and F Mercuri, "Two decades of Jameson Cell installations in coal," to be presented at ''The 17th International Coal Preparation Congress, Istanbul, 1–6 October 2013''.</ref> It is mainly used in metals applications to solve final grade and capacity issues from conventional cell cleaner circuits.<ref name = "Araya"/> It has found a niche in transforming traditional circuit designs where its inclusion allows cleaner circuits to be designed with fewer cells in a smaller footprint, while achieving cleaner and/or higher grade concentrates.<ref name = "Araya"/> It has also made possible the recovery of previously discarded fine materials, such as coal<ref name = "Honaker">R Q Honaker, A Patwardhan, M K Mohanty and K U Bhaskar, "Fine coal cleaning using Jameson Cells: the North American experience," in: ''Advances in Flotation Technology'' (The Society of Mining, Metallurgy and Exploration: Littelton, Colorado, 1999), 331–341. {{ISBN|0-87335-184-3}}.</ref> and phosphate fines,<ref name = "Teague">A J Teague and M C Lollback, "The beneficiation of ultrafine phosphate," ''Minerals Engineering'', '''27–28''', (2012), 52–59.</ref> thereby increasing the efficiency and extending the life of the world's non-renewable natural resources.
==Operating principles==
Froth flotation is achieved by mixing chemicals known as collectors with the ore slurry. The collectors adsorb onto the surfaces of the particles of select minerals (usually the valuable mineral that is targeted for concentration), making these minerals hydrophobic. Air is passed through the slurry in a tank known as a flotation cell. The air is broken into tiny bubbles by various mechanisms (depending on the design of the flotation cell), and the now-hydrophobic minerals attach to the bubbles, rising with them to the surface of the flotation cell, where they form a [[froth]]. The froth flows over the top edge (or "lip") of the flotation cell and forms the flotation concentrate. Ideally, none of the unwanted mineral particles float, and they remain behind as the flotation [[tailings]].
However, the selectivity of the collection mechanism is not perfect. Some unwanted ("[[gangue]]") minerals are also carried into the froth, largely by entrainment with the water rising with the bubbles. This is particularly the case for particles less than 10 [[µm]] in size.<ref name = "Johnson2002">N W Johnson and P D Munro, "Overview of flotation technology and plant practice for complex sulphide [sic] ores," in: ''Mineral Processing Plant Design, Practice and Control'', Eds A L Mular, D N Halbe and D J Barratt (Society for Mining, Metallurgy and Exploration: Littleton, Colorado, 2002), 1097–1123.</ref> Some of the gangue particles follow the water between the bubbles as it drains back to the underlying pulp. This process can be assisted by the application of sufficient "wash water" to the froth to displace the water entrained with the bubbles and the fine gangue particles brought with them.<ref name = "Jameson1992"/> Column flotation cells, invented in Canada by Boutin and Tremblay in 1961,<ref name = "Clingan">B V Clingan and D R McGregor, "Column flotation experience at Magma Copper Company, with related experience of other mineral processors," presented at the ''SME Annual Meeting, Denver, Colorado, 24–27 February 1987''. Preprint 87-91.</ref> grew increasingly popular in the 1980s and 1990s as a way of reducing entrainment of fine gangue particles during "cleaning" of flotation concentrates.<ref name = "Johnson2002"/><ref name = "Lane">G S Lane and R C Dunne, "Column flotation – an Australian perspective," in: ''The AusIMM Kalgoorlie Branch, Equipment in the Minerals Industry: Exploration, Mining and Processing Conference, Kalgoorlie, Western Australia, October 1987'' (The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy: Melbourne, 1987), 81–93.</ref> With heights usually between 6 and 14 meters,<ref name = "Dobby">G Dobby, "Column Flotation," in: ''Mineral Processing Plant Design, Practice and Control'', Eds A L Mular, D N Halbe and D J Barratt (Society for Mining, Metallurgy and Exploration: Littleton, Colorado, 2002), 1239–1252.</ref> they could have froth depths up to 2 m,<ref name = "Lane"/> providing more residence time than conventional cells and more stable froth surfaces that enable better froth washing. [[File:FlCell.PNG|thumbnail|Figure 2. A schematic diagram illustrating the operating principles of a conventional, mechanically agitated flotation cell.]]
Froth flotation efficiency is determined by a series of probabilities: those of particle–bubble contact, particle–bubble attachment, transport between the pulp and the froth, and froth collection into the product launder.<ref name = "Atkinson">B W Atkinson, C J Conway and G J Jameson, "Fundamentals of Jameson Cell operation including size–yield response," in: ''Sixth Australian Coal Preparation Conference, Mackay, Queensland, 6–9 September 1993'' (The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy: Melbourne, 1993).</ref>
In a conventional mechanically agitated cell, the void fraction is low (5–10%) and the bubble size is large (2–3 mm), which results in a low interfacial area with a low probability of particle–bubble contact.<ref name = "Atkinson"/> In a conventional flotation column, the void fraction is similarly low, and so the probability of particle–bubble contact is increased by increasing the height of the column to provide greater residence time.<ref name = "Atkinson"/>
Traditionally, the ore slurry and the air are introduced separately to the flotation cell (see Figure 2). The Jameson Cell differs from this traditional approach by mixing the slurry with the air in the downcomers. [[File:Jameson Cell downcomer.png|thumbnail|Figure 3. The Jameson Cell downcomer.]]
The slurry is introduced at the top of the downcomer as a jet that draws in air through a second pipe to form a stable two-phase mixture (see Figure 3).<ref name = "Jameson1991"/> The plunging slurry jet shears and then entrains the air.<ref name = "Harbort2004">G Harbort, J Cowburn and E V Manlapig, [http://www.jamesoncell.com/EN/Downloads/technical%20papers/Recovery%20interactions%20between%20the%20froth%20zone,%20pulp%20zone%20and%20downcomer%20within%20a%20Jameson%20Cell.pdf. "Recovery interactions between the froth zone, pulp zone and downcomer within a Jameson Cell,"] in: ''10th Australian Coal Preparation Conference, Pokolbin, New South Wales, 17–21 October 2004'' (The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy: Melbourne, 2004). Accessed: 23 May 2013.</ref> The target minerals, with their collector-coated surfaces, attach to the bubbles and this mixture travels down the downcomer, driven by hydrostatic forces,<ref name = "Evans">G M Evans, B W Atkinson and G J Jameson, [http://www.jamesoncell.com/EN/Downloads/technical%20papers/The%20Jameson%20Cell.pdf. "The Jameson Cell,"] In: ''Flotation Science and Engineering'', Ed. K A Matis (Marcel Dekker: New York, 1995), 331–363. Accessed 24 May 2013.</ref> before it is discharged into the tank portion of the Jameson Cell (see Figure 4).<ref name = "Jameson1991"/> The downcomer is designed to provide high-intensity mixing of the air and the slurry to generate a dense foam of fine bubbles and maximise the contact between the target mineral particles and the bubbles.<ref name = "Jameson1991a">G J Jameson and E V Manlapig, "Flotation cell design – experiences with the Jameson Cell," in: ''Extractive Metallurgy Conference, Perth, Western Australia, 2–4 October 1991'' (The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy: Melbourne, 1991), 1–6.</ref> The probability of particle–bubble contact is "virtually 100%" with a slurry residence time in the downcomer of 5–10 seconds.<ref name = "Atkinson"/> [[File:Diagram of a Jameson Cell.png|thumbnail|Figure 4. A cut-away drawing showing a typical Jameson Cell design.]]
The high probability of particle–bubble contact, and subsequent short residence times (five to ten seconds in the downcomer,<ref name = "Atkinson"/> allows for a much more compact column design than conventional column flotation cells (see Figure 1).<ref name = "Jameson1992"/> The fine nature of the bubbles (0.3 to 0.5 mm in diameter<ref name = "Barns2009"/>) gives them enhanced carrying capabilities for fine mineral particles.<ref name = "Jameson1992"/> Fine bubbles also improve the separation of minerals, as they intensify the difference in the flotation kinetics of the valuable minerals from the gangue minerals, thus allowing higher grade concentrates to be produced.<ref name = "Araya"/>
The foam in the downcomer is about 50–60% air.<ref name = "Jameson1991a"/> Because of this, the pulp is distributed in the form of thin interfacial slurry films between the bubbles, providing an ideal environment for particle–bubble contact.<ref name = "Atkinson"/> Collection occurs by migration of the particles within the thin films, which are not much thicker than the diameter of the particles.<ref name = "Jameson1991a"/>
The best collection occurs when the volume of air roughly equals that of the injected slurry.<ref name = "Jameson1991a"/>
The Cell is operated by initially closing the air inlet at the top of the downcomer and feeding the flotation pulp in through the nozzle.<ref name = "Evans"/> The air in the downcomer is entrained in the pulp, creating a partial vacuum that draws pulp from the tank up into the downcomer.<ref name = "Evans"/> The pulp level quickly reaches the nozzle, which is at a level above that of the liquid level in the tank.<ref name = "Evans"/> This creates a hydrostatic head in the downcomer, meaning that the pressure inside the top of the downcomer is lower than the atmospheric pressure.<ref name = "Evans"/> When the inlet is opened, air is drawn into the top space of the downcomer by this lower pressure, where it too is entrained into the downcomer contents by the plunging jet.<ref name = "Evans"/> At the same time, a downward flow is established in the pulp in the downcomer that is sufficient to counter the buoyancy of the bubbles, and the aerated pulp discharges into the tank.<ref name = "Evans"/>
Once in the tank, the wider cross sectional area of the tank reduces the downward superficial velocity of the mixture,<ref name = "Evans"/> allowing mineral-laden bubbles to disengage from the liquid<ref name = "Evans"/> and rise to the surface as they would in a conventional cell, where they form the froth.<ref name = "Jameson1991"/> The velocity of the mixture discharging into the tank, and the large density differential between it and the remainder of the pulp in the tank, results in recirculating fluid patterns that keep the particles in the tank in suspension without requiring mechanical agitation.<ref name = "Harbort2004"/>
The purpose of the tank is simply for bubble–pulp separation, so the volume of the tank is small compared with alternative technologies.<ref name = "Barns2009"/>
The froth that forms at the top of the tank flows over its lip to be collected. This froth can be "washed" by a light flow of water, if desired.<ref name = "Readett"/> The bubbles flowing over the lip of the cell are smaller in diameter than those that flow over the lip of conventional flotation columns.<ref name = "Young2013"/>
The non-floating tailings are discharged through a hole in the bottom of the tank.<ref name = "Jameson1992"/>
The Cell has no moving parts and no requirement for compressed air or sparging mechanisms.<ref name = "Carretta">M F Carretta, J N Graham and W J Dawson, [http://www.jamesoncell.com/EN/Downloads/technical%20papers/Goonyella%20Scale-Up%20Paper.pdf. "Jameson Cell scale-up experiences at BHP Coal's Goonyella coal preparation plant,"] Presented at: ''Coal Prep '97, Lexington, Kentucky, 29 April – 1 May 1997''. Accessed 29 May 2013.</ref> This results in lower power consumption than the equivalent mechanical or column flotation cells.<ref name = "Barns2009"/> Maintenance costs are also lower because the only wearing part is the slurry lens used to create the jet in the downcomer.<ref name = "Barns2009"/>
==History==
The Jameson Cell grew out of a long-term research program aimed at improving the recovery of fine particles by flotation. The work started at [[Imperial College London]], and continued when Jameson moved in 1978 to the University of Newcastle, NSW, Australia, where he is Laureate Professor (2015).
===Academic research (1969–1990)===
Jameson’s research into flotation began when he was at Imperial College London, in 1969. A colleague, Dr J A Kitchener of the Royal School of Mines, pointed out that many of the new mineral deposits being found around the world required fine grinding to separate the valuable particles from the rock in which they were embedded, and the flotation technologies available at the time were relatively inefficient for recovering fine particles. Kitchener felt that improvements could best be achieved by an increased knowledge of the physics of flotation, rather than the chemistry of the reagents. Jameson had gained some expertise in the properties of bubbles and particles in suspensions whilst a PhD student at Cambridge. He began research into the fluid mechanics of the flotation process and set in train a series of experimental projects into the effect of particle diameter and bubble size on the flotation rate constant. Much of the research was conducted by honours students in chemical engineering. Jameson accepted the challenge of coming up with practical solutions to remedy the situation, if these could be identified.
Jameson’s research showed that the kinetics of flotation of fine particles was a strong function of the bubble diameter<ref name = "Collins1976">Collins, G.L. and Jameson, G.J., 1976. Experiments on the flotation of fine particles - the effect of particle size and charge. Chemical Engineering Science 31, 985.</ref><ref name = "Ahmed1985">Ahmed, N.A. and Jameson, G.J., 1985. The effect of bubble size on the rate of flotation of fine particles, International Journal of Mineral Processing 14, 195-215.</ref> and that the way to improve recoveries was to use small bubbles in the order of 300 µm in diameter. What was needed was a practical method of making such bubbles in large quantities, of the order of billions per second. The device needed to be simple to construct and operate, capable of running for long periods with minimal maintenance, and should be resistant to blockage by stray large particles in the feed. He began to look at the theory of bubble breakup in sheared flows, that is, in flow fields in which layers of liquid slide over each other. Lewis and Davidson<ref name = "Lewis1982">Lewis, D.A. and Davidson, J.F., 1982. Bubble splitting in shear flow. Trans IChemE, 60: 283-291.</ref> had recently published a theory to predict the maximum size of bubbles in a well-characterised flow environment. By balancing the forces acting on a bubble in a shearing flow, including the disruptive dynamic stresses from the liquid motion and the restoring force of surface tension, it was possible to predict the critical shear rate required to produce a bubble of given size. Jameson then looked for simple and practical ways of generating the required shear rates, and found inspiration in the kitchen sink. If a jet of water from a tap plunges into a basin full of water, a shear layer develops around the jet, that entrains air from the atmosphere into the water, and at the same time, breaks up the entrained air into fine bubbles. The effect is magnified if there is a detergent in the water. Detergents, known as frothers, are used in flotation to prevent bubble coalescence, and to create stable froths. By the correct choice of jet velocity and diameter, it is possible to provide a controlled shear environment that can generate bubbles of a suitable size for flotation, with the added advantage that the air is naturally aspirated by the jet, so there is no need for a compressor or blower. Thus the idea of the Jameson Cell was born.
After a number of failures, the radical new process for flotation emerged in the laboratory at the University of Newcastle. Jameson filed a provisional patent application in 1986. After an initial trial at the [[Renison Bell]] tin mine in Tasmania, certain design features were modified. He led a further plant trial with a small cell in the lead-zinc concentrator at [[Mount Isa Mines|Mt Isa Mines Ltd]] in Queensland, initially working alone. The plant metallurgists took an interest in the technology and helped to refine it, particularly checking the scale-up procedures that Jameson had devised. In 1988 a recent graduate was assigned full-time for a year to verify and validate the performance of the Cell. In 1989 a worldwide exclusive license was negotiated between Tunra Ltd on behalf of the University of Newcastle, Jameson, and MIM Holdings Limited, for the use of the Cell for metallurgical purposes. Summary papers on the theory<ref name = "Jameson1993">Jameson, G.J., 1993. Bubbles in motion, Transactions of the Institution of Chemical Engineers A71, 587-594.</ref> and practice<ref name = "Evans"/> have been published.
There have been ongoing significant changes to the design of the Cell since it was first developed in the late 1980s.
===Trouble in the mill (1980s)===
The commercial development of the Cell occurred indirectly as a result of problems being experienced in MIM's Mount Isa lead–zinc concentrator (sometimes referred to as a "mill" in the mining industry). MIM had been operating a lead–zinc concentrator at Mount Isa since 1931,<ref name = "Young2000">M F Young, J D Pease and K S Fisher, "The George Fisher project to increase recovery in the Mount Isa lead/zinc concentrator," in: ''Seventh Mill Operators' Conference, Kalgoorlie, Western Australia, 12–14 October 2000'' (The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy: Melbourne, 2000), 157–163.</ref> although lead–zinc ore was substituted with copper ore for a time between mid-1943 and mid-1946.<ref>G Blainey, ''Mines in the Spinifex'', (Angus and Robertson: Sydney, 1960), 182–191.</ref> Over time, the lead, zinc and other mineral grains in the ore became progressively finer, the ore grade decreased and it became more difficult to treat.<ref name = "Young1997">M F Young, J D Pease, N W Johnson and P D Munro, "Developments in milling practice at the lead/zinc concentrator of Mount Isa Mines Limited from 1990," in: ''AusIMM Sixth Mill Operators' Conference, Madang, Papua New Guinea, 6–8 October 1997'' (The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy: Melbourne, 1997), 3–12.</ref> These trends, combined with an increase in the concentrator's throughput, significantly reduced the concentrator's performance in the 1980s, resulting in a "tense" period of "an endless circle of circuit changes, reagent changes, operator changes, metallurgist changes, and so on".<ref name = "Young1997"/> The decreasing grain size and pushing the grinding circuit beyond its design throughput meant a reduction in the degree of separation of the individual mineral grains (referred to as "liberation") during grinding. From 1984 to 1991, the liberation of [[sphalerite]] (the zinc-bearing mineral, ZnS) decreased from almost 70% to just over 50%.<ref name = "Young1997"/> This decrease in liberation resulted in a reduction in the recovery of zinc to saleable zinc concentrate.<ref name = "Young1997"/>
The initial response to the problem of decreased zinc recovery was in 1986 to start to produce a lower-grade concentrate that was a mixture of zinc and lead (known in the industry as a "bulk concentrate" and referred to at Mount Isa as the "low-grade middlings concentrate").<ref name = "Young1997"/> This concentrate typically contained 34% zinc and 13% lead, compared to the normal zinc concentrate composition of at least 50% zinc and less than 3% lead.<ref name = "Young1997"/>
By producing the bulk concentrate, the total recovery of zinc for sale was maintained at over 70% until 1989.<ref name = "Young1997"/> However, the high lead content meant that the bulk concentrate could not be treated by the [[Zinc smelting#Electrolysis process|electrolytic zinc process]], and it had to be sold to zinc smelters using the more-expensive [[Zinc smelting#Blast furnace process (Imperial Smelting Process)|Imperial Smelting Process]]. Initially, MIM received good revenue from its bulk concentrate, but as the nature of the ore continued to deteriorate, the production of the bulk concentrate increased and saturated the market. Payment terms declined until MIM received less than half the payment for zinc in the bulk concentrate than it received for zinc in the zinc concentrate.<ref name = "Young1997"/>
The problems in the concentrator also affected the performance of MIM's Mount Isa lead smelter.<ref name = "Young1997"/><ref name = "Pease1997">J D Pease, M F Young, C J Greet, N W Johnson and P D Munro, "Application of fine grinding to improve galena flotation at the Mt Isa Mines lead/zinc concentrator," presented at: ''39th Annual AMIRA Technical Meeting, Adelaide, 11 September 1997''.</ref> The lead–zinc ore also contained increasing amounts of fine-grained, carbonaceous [[pyrite]] (FeS<sub>2</sub>).<ref name = "Young1997"/> This material was naturally hydrophobic and floated without the aid of a collector into the lead concentrate, diluting it. The additional sulfur from the pyrite in the lead concentrate reduced the lead smelter's lead production because the ability to eliminate sulfur from the concentrate was lead smelter's capacity bottleneck.<ref name = "Young1997"/>
As part of the effort to try to fix the problems, MIM installed some column flotation cells in the zinc concentrate and bulk concentrate sections of the plant.<ref name = "Young1997"/> In those days, the air was introduced into flotation columns using air spargers, usually in the form of a bag or sheath around a pipe.<ref name = "Lane"/> The spargers were high-maintenance items, and their performance was critical to the operation of the column.<ref name = "Lane"/>
===Inception and early development (1985–1990)===
====Lead and zinc flotation====
In 1985, MIM commissioned Jameson to undertake a project to improve the sparger design for flotation columns.<ref name = "Cowburn">J A Cowburn, R Stone, S Bourke and B Hill, "Design developments of the Jameson Cell," in: ''Centenary of Flotation Symposium, Brisbane, Queensland, 6–9 June 2005'' (The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy: Melbourne, 2005), 193–199.</ref> Instead, he developed the concept of using a jet in a downcomer to create the bubbles and eliminate the need for a sparger in conventional flotation columns.<ref name = "Cowburn"/>
The concept of the Cell followed when further investigations showed that most of the bubble–particle interactions were occurring in the downcomer, rendering unnecessary the collection zone of flotation columns.<ref name = "Cowburn"/> The idea of the downcomer and short separation tank was developed and a provisional patent application was lodged in 1986.<ref name = "Cowburn"/> This patent was later assigned to TUNRA Limited ("TUNRA"),<ref name = "Cowburn"/> the technology transfer company of the University of Newcastle that is now known as "Newcastle Innovation".<ref>[http://www.bulksolids.com.au/about_us.html "TUNRA Bulk Solids – Who We Are."] Accessed 1 June 2013.</ref><ref>[http://www.newcastleinnovation.com.au/about-newcastle-innovation#.UampkPWQ8-U "About Newcastle Innovation."] Accessed 1 June 2013.</ref>
A pilot two tonne per hour (t/h) Jameson Cell with a 100 mm downcomer and using an orifice plate to create the jet was tested in MIM's lead–zinc concentrator.<ref name = "Cowburn"/> Subsequently, in 1988, MIM tested the flotation of a stream of fine lead-bearing particles in a conventional mechanical flotation cell, a conventional column and the Jameson Cell.<ref name = "Cowburn"/> The Cell gave the best recoveries.<ref name = "Cowburn"/> This was thought to be a combination of the short residence time of the particles in the Cell and the fact that the [[hydrophobicity]] of the lead particles decreased over time.<ref name = "Cowburn"/>
As a result of this work, in 1989 MIM ordered four full-scale Cells, two for the Mount Isa lead–zinc concentrator and another two for the new Hilton lead–zinc concentrator<ref name = "Cowburn"/> to be built at the Hilton Mine, located about 20 kilometers north of Mount Isa.<ref name = "Rohner">P Rohner, "Lead-zinc-silver ore concentration practice at the Hilton Concentrator of Mount Isa Mines Limited, Mount Isa, Qld," in: ''Australasian Mining and Metallurgy, The Sir Maurice Mawby Memorial Volume, Second Edition'', Eds. J T Woodcock and J K Hamilton (The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy: Melbourne, 1993), 504–507.</ref> The Mount Isa cells had diameters of 1.9 m,<ref name = "Munro1993">P D Munro, "Lead-zinc-silver ore concentration practice at the lead-zinc concentrator of Mount Isa Mines Limited, Mount Isa, Qld," in: ''Australasian Mining and Metallurgy, The Sir Maurice Mawby Memorial Volume, Second Edition'', Eds. J T Woodcock and J K Hamilton (The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy: Melbourne, 1993), 498–503.</ref> with three downcomers each,<ref name = "Installations"/> while those at Hilton were 1.3 m in diameter<ref name = "Rohner"/> and had two downcomers each.<ref name = "Installations"/>
====Coal flotation====
In parallel with this work, the Cell was tested for the recovery of fine coal at the [[Newlands coal mine]], also owned by MIM Holdings Limited.<ref name = "Cowburn"/> This fines stream was [[Hydrocyclone|cyclone]] [[Hydrocyclone#Design|overflow]], which contained 15–50% ash and was previously discarded.<ref name = "Osborne"/> The particle size of this stream was less than 25 µm.<ref name = "Osborne"/> Pilot plant testing showed that it was possible to achieve greater than 90% recovery of coal, with less than 10% ash in the product.<ref name = "Osborne"/>
Subsequently, a full-scale plant was commissioned at Newlands in the 1988–89 financial year, with six rectangular Cells (1.5 m × 3.5 m) installed in a two-stage arrangement.<ref name = "Cowburn"/> The cells in the first stage had seven downcomers, while those in the second had six.<ref name = "Cowburn"/> These cells were in continuous operation at Newlands for 15 years until a new washing plant was built to replace the old one in 2006.<ref name = "Osborne"/>
Two additional Cells were installed at MIM Holdings' Collinsville Coal operations in 1990. These had 10 downcomers each.<ref name = "Installations"/>
====Copper flotation====
Also in 1989, Peko Mines, then a division of [[North Broken Hill Peko Limited]], also engaged Jameson to undertake test work in its Warrego concentrator near [[Tennant Creek]] in Australia's [[Northern Territory]].<ref name = "Jameson1991"/> The objective was to determine the Jameson Cell's performance in [[Froth flotation#Cleaning|cleaning]] copper concentrate to improve its grade by removing gangue minerals, including pyrite, [[magnetite]], [[hematite]] and [[quartz]].<ref name = "Jameson1991"/> Peko Mines personnel also tested a conventional flotation column for comparison. Following the test work, Peko Mines installed two full-scale, 1.4 m diameter Jameson Cells in the concentrator, each with three downcomers.<ref name = "Jameson1991"/>
Peko Mines' decision was based on:
* metallurgical performance during pilot plant test work * lower capital expenditure and installation costs * shorter construction and installation times * ease of operation and lower expected maintenance costs.<ref name = "Jameson1991"/>
Peko Mines reported a payback on the investment in the Cells of two months.<ref name = "Jameson1991"/>
====Electrolyte cleaning in solvent extraction – electrowinning plants====
[[Solvent extraction]] – [[electrowinning]] (often referred to as "SX–EW") is a process frequently applied for recovering copper from low-grade and/or oxidised copper ore. It involves leaching the copper from the ore using an acidic solution, collecting the leach liquor containing the copper and contacting this solution with an organic extractant. The copper ions in the leach liquor transfer to the organic extractant, moving from a relatively low concentration to a higher concentration. The extractant is subsequently brought into contact with a second aqueous solution that is more acid than the original leach liquor, and the copper again moves, this time from the extractant into the aqueous solution. The result is an acidic solution of copper in which the copper concentration is high enough for it to be recovered by electrowinning. The solution destined for electrowinning is known as the [[electrolyte]].<ref>P Hayes, ''Process Principles in Minerals & Materials Production'' (Hayes Publishing Company: Sherwood, Queensland, 1993), 227–314.</ref>
The electrolyte solution usually contains traces of the organic extractant that exist as tiny droplets within it.<ref name = "Readett1993">D Readett, "Copper recovery by heap leaching, solvent extraction, and electrowinning at Mount Isa Mines Limited, Mount Isa, Qld," in: ''Australasian Mining and Metallurgy – The Sir Maurice Mawby Memorial Volume, 2nd Edition'' (The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy: Melbourne, 1993), 721–725.</ref> These need to be removed before the copper can be recovered in the electrowinning process, as the presence of minimal amounts of the extractant can cause difficulties by stripping and damaging the cathodes with a subsequent loss of cathode copper quality.<ref>Xstrata Technology, [http://www.jamesoncell.com/EN/Downloads/Documents/brochure_en.pdf "Jameson Cell – Rising to the Challenge."]</ref>
In the late 1980s, MIM built an SX–EW plant at Mount Isa to recover copper leached from low grade ore stockpiled while mining its [[Mount Isa Mines#From survival to prosperity (1946–1973)|Black Rock open cut]] in the 1960s.<ref name = "Readett1993"/> In a world first, a Jameson Cell was used to clean the electrolyte solution by removing the remaining organic solvent.<ref name = "Readett1993"/> This replaced the sand filters traditionally used.<ref name = "Readett"/>
The cell was 3 m high, twice the height of the early Cells used in MIM's lead–zinc concentrators, as it was thought that additional residence time would enhance recovery.<ref name = "Readett"/> It used a single downcomer.<ref name = "Installations"/> The downcomer was used to contact the electrolyte with air and the droplets of the organic extractant attached themselves to the air bubbles created in the downcomer.<ref name = "Readett1993"/>
After some initial modifications to the orifice size, the Cell was able to remove 70–90% of the entrained organic extractant.<ref name = "Readett"/>
====Early spread of the technology====
In April 1989, MIM Holdings Limited acquired the world rights to the Jameson Cell from TUNRA, with TUNRA retaining the rights to use the Cell for waste water treatment.<ref name = "Cowburn"/>
After the initial applications within the MIM Holdings group of companies, the years to 1994 saw Jameson Cells installed by various base and precious metals companies in Asia, South Africa, Canada and the United States, mainly in concentrate cleaning duties, but also in SX–EW electrolyte cleaning duties.<ref name = "Installations"/> The installation by Phelps Dodge (now [[Freeport-McMoRan]]) for electrolyte cleaning at its Morenci operation in Arizona was notable for having a large cell 6.5 m in diameter with 30 downcomers.<ref name = "Installations"/> The Morenci Jameson Cell consistently recovered over 82% of the organic extractant.<ref name = "Readett"/>
Toward the end of the period, Cells were installed in coal preparation plants operated by the BHP Mitsubishi Alliance and by Peabody for fines recovery.<ref name = "Installations"/>
====Early design developments====
Improvements to this early design included a focus on the weight and wear of the downcomer.<ref name = "Cowburn"/> The downcomer was originally built with [[polyurethane]]-lined steel, and then changed to a [[high-density polyethylene]] ("HDPE") construction with seven elements.<ref name = "Cowburn"/>
The orifice plate used to generate the slurry jet was a high-wear item and its materials of construction were also a focus of the development effort.<ref name = "Cowburn"/> After testing high-chromium hardened steel and various ceramics, high-density alumina was found to have excellent wear properties, and it became the standard.<ref name = "Cowburn"/>
===The Mark II Cell (1994–1999)===
====Mark II improvements====
The original Jameson Cell design had the following features: * small (200 mm diameter) downcomers * no wash water * no tailings recycle * no bubble dispersers * low capacity.<ref name = "Osborne"/>
In 1994 MIM launched the Mark II model Cell.<ref name = "Osborne"/> It incorporated the following changes: * the downcomer diameter was increased to 280 mm<ref name = "Osborne"/> * wash-water trays were included for froth washing<ref name = "Osborne"/> * a tailings recycle system was added to maintain constant downcomer flow and higher recoveries<ref name = "Osborne"/> * conical bubble dispersers were added<ref name = "Osborne"/> * increased depth of tank from the bottom of the downcomer<ref name = "Cowburn"/> * increased distance between the downcomers.<ref name = "Cowburn"/> [[File:Jameson Cell external recycle mechanism.png|thumbnail|Figure 5. Drawing of a Jameson Cell fitted with an external tailings recycle mechanism.]]
These changes resulted in a higher capacity design.<ref name = "Osborne"/>
One of the problems encountered with the Mark I Cell was that its performance was reduced if the feed rate to the cell varied, which was a common occurrence arising from normal fluctuations in operating concentrators.<ref name = "Young2013"/> This problem was resolved by recycling some of the tailings to the cell feed via an external splitter box called an "External Recycle Mechanism" or "ERM" box separate to the flotation cell.<ref name = "Young2013"/> Thus, when the production of the feed stream to the Jameson Cell decreased as a result of a fluctuation elsewhere in the concentrator, a higher percentage of the tailings was automatically recycled to the downcomers, producing a constant flow rate, hence feed pressure, to the cell.<ref name = "Young2013"/> This had the added benefit of giving a proportion of the tailings (typically 40%) a second pass through the system, which resulted in higher recoveries.<ref name = "Young2013"/> In coal fines flotation, this allowed a single Cell to achieve the same recovery of combustibles as had previously been achieved in some two-stage Cell systems.<ref name = "Osborne"/>
Subsequently, an internal recycling system, referred to as the "internal recycle control" or "IRC" was developed. This was mainly used in integrated rectangular cells (see Figure 6), where the feed tank and tailings recycling system could easily be built in a single unit with the flotation cell. This system reduced the cell installation costs and made the cell more compact.<ref name = "Young2013"/> [[File:Jameson Cell with internal tailings recycle mechanism.png|thumbnail|Figure 6. Drawing of a Jameson Cell designed with an internal tailings recycling system.]]
During this period, the orifice diameter was increased from the 28 mm design used in 1990 to 34 mm with the Mark II model and 38 mm in 1997.<ref name = "Cowburn"/> This, together with the larger Mark II downcomer diameter, allowed the slurry flow per downcomer to be doubled from 30 m<sup>3</sup>/h in 1990 to 60 m<sup>3</sup>/h in 1997.<ref name = "Cowburn"/>
The increased distance between the downcomers reduced the interaction of aerated slurry discharging from adjacent downcomers.<ref name = "Cowburn"/> This interaction could reduce overall cell recovery by causing particles collected by bubbles in the downcomer to detach in the pulp tank.<ref name = "Cowburn"/>
There was significant turbulence in the areas beneath the downcomers.<ref name = "Cowburn"/> that could result in particles detaching from bubbles.<ref name = "Cowburn"/> These turbulent areas were calmed by the addition of conical diffusers beneath each downcomer.<ref name = "Cowburn"/> They allowed uniform bubble rise velocities across the surface of the cell by slowing the superficial gas velocity in the high void-fraction area immediately around the downcomer and provided a more even bubble dispersion.<ref name = "Cowburn"/> It was reported that the diffusers reduced the turbulence by 69% compared with a standard downcomer with no diffuser.<ref name = "Cowburn"/>
====New applications====
While the JamesonCell continued to expand in base metals concentrate cleaning, SX–EW electrolyte cleaning and coal fines recovery applications, it also found new applications in cleaning potash slimes<ref name = "Burns">M J Burns, G Coates and L Barnard, "Use of Jameson Cell flotation technology at Cleveland Potash Ltd, North Yorkshire, England," ''Transactions of the Institution of Mining and Metallurgy (Section C: Mineral Processing and Extractive Metallurgy)'', May–August 1994, C162–C167.</ref> and was adopted by the Philex Mining Corporation as the sole flotation machine for its Benguet copper concentrator.<ref name = "Harbort1997">G J Harbort, A S Murphy and A Budod, "Jameson Cell developments at Philex Mining Corporation," in: ''AusIMM Sixth Mill Operators' Conference, Madang, Papua New Guinea, 6–8 October 1997'' (The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy: Melbourne, 1997), 105–113.</ref> This is not the normal application for the Cell. No other metals concentrator operates solely using Jameson Cells.<ref name = "Installations"/>
=====Potash flotation=====
Cleveland Potash Limited extracts and refines sylvinite ore from a deposit in North Yorkshire, England.<ref name = "Burns"/> Its processing plant uses froth flotation to produce a product rich in [[potassium chloride]] ("KCl").<ref name = "Burns"/> After a test work campaign in which it compared the performance of the Cell with mechanical flotation cells in various duties in the flotation circuit, Cleveland Potash ordered a Cell with 6 downcomers for recovering potash slimes.<ref name = "Installations"/> The test work had shown a 4.8% increase in the recovery of potash slimes, equivalent at the time to an increase in revenue of approximately £518,000 per year.<ref name = "Burns"/>
=====Copper rougher flotation=====
In 1993 Philex Mining Corporation, a Philippines mining company, replaced the mechanical cleaner circuit with Cells at its Benguet copper concentrator.<ref name = "Harbort1997"/> Following their successful operation, Philex replaced the mechanical cells in its cleaner-scavenger circuit in 1994 and began the phased introduction of Cell rougher and scavenger lines that was completed in early 1996.<ref name = "Harbort1997"/> This was the first operation in which the external recycle mechanism system was applied.<ref name = "Young2013"/> By the time the last Jameson Cell was installed, the entire flotation circuit was composed of Jameson Cells.<ref name = "Harbort1997"/>
The motivation for installing Jameson Cells was, in part, to take advantage of their space-saving capabilities and to improve copper recovery at a minimum cost.<ref name = "Harbort1997"/> The Cell circuit occupied 60% less floor area and achieved equivalent results to the mechanical banks with 40% of their residence time.<ref name = "Harbort1997"/> They provided a power saving of 18%.<ref name = "Harbort1997"/>
In addition to these benefits, the use of the Jameson Cells in the rougher and rougher–scavenger section of the plant resulted in a 3.3% increase in copper recovery and a 4.5% increase in gold recovery.<ref name = "Harbort1997"/> When combined with the other Cells in the cleaner, recleaner and cleaner–scavenger section, there was a 2.6% increase in final copper concentrate grade and a 3.5% increase in plant copper recovery, with a 2.6% increase in plant gold recovery.<ref name = "Harbort1997"/>
===The Mark III Cell (2000–2008)===
====Mark III improvements==== [[File:Jameson Cell Mark IV slurry lens.png|thumbnail|Figure 7. The Jameson Cell Mark IV slurry lens.]]
The Mark III design encompassed the greatest improvement in the technology since its commercialisation. The focus was to make the technology more robust and easier to use in operations. The total redesign of the downcomer assembly allowed it to be isolated and unblocked much more easily compared to the Mark II design. The Mark III design also saw slurry flow per downcomer to be increased from 60 m<sup>3</sup>/h to 75–85 m<sup>3</sup>/h using larger orifice sizes in the slurry lenses.<ref name = "LH">Personal communication, L Huynh, Jameson Cell Manager, Xstrata Technology.</ref>
The Mark III Cell was introduced in 2000. It included the following improvements: * a new slurry lens orifice design (see Figures 7 and 8) * a new design downcomer and nozzle * a new design flat plate bubble dispersers * a stainless steel adjustable above and in-froth wash water system (see Figure 9) * automated air and wash water flow control * air-isolating slurry-eliminating valves ("AISE valves") * a bottom-fed new slurry distributor.<ref name = "Osborne"/> [[File:Photograph of Jameson Cell slurry lens.png|thumbnail|Figure 8. A Jameson Cell slurry lens being inserted into the top of a downcomer.]]
The earlier models of the Jameson Cell used [[orifice plate]]s to generate the downcomer jet.<ref name = "Young2013"/> The new slurry lens design had a smooth, shallow entry angle that created an optimum flow regime over the ceramic, reducing wear and extending its life.<ref name = "Cowburn"/> The shape resulted in a decrease in power consumption by the feed slurry pump by up to 10% and resulted in better jet formation that improved air entrainment.<ref name = "Cowburn"/> [[File:Jameson Cell coal froth washing.png|thumbnail|Figure 9. A stainless-steel wash water system fitted to a Jameson Cell being used for floating coal fines.]]
For coal applications, the wash water addition system was changed from a tray to stainless-steel circular rings attached to a manual lifting system.<ref name = "Cowburn"/> This allowed the flexibility of an easy transition from above-froth wash water addition to the in-froth addition that might be necessary for high concentrate-grade operations.<ref name = "Cowburn"/> For metals applications, new design wash water trays consisting of removable rubber mats for easy maintenance were used.<ref name = "LH"/>
The AISE valves were developed to prevent solids being sucked back into the air lines when individual downcomers become blocked. Solids depositing in the air lines and their build up in the air distributor decreases flotation performance as it prevents air from being efficiently entrained in the downcomers.<ref name = "Cowburn"/>
====New applications====
This period was one of rapid growth for the Jameson Cells in the existing applications.<ref name = "Installations"/> Seventy-seven Cells were installed in concentrators around the world, mainly in coal and base metal operations.<ref name = "Installations"/> However, during this time, the Cell also moved into the Canadian [[oil sands]] industry for the flotation of bitumen.<ref name = "Installations"/>
=====Bitumen flotation=====
Flotation is one of the unit processes used to separate the bituminous component of oil sands as part of the process of oil extraction.<ref name = "Neiman">O Neiman, B Hilscher and R Siy, [http://www.jamesoncell.com/EN/Downloads/technical%20papers/Secondary%20Recovery%20of%20Bitumen%20using%20Jameson%20Downcomers.pdf "Secondary recovery of bitumen using Jameson downcomers,"] in: ''Proceedings of the 44th Canadian Mineral Processors Operators Conference, Ottawa, Ontario, 17–19 January 2012'' (Canadian Institute of Mining, Metallurgy and Petroleum), 115–124. Accessed 24 May 2013.</ref> Some of the bitumen is not recovered in the primary separation vessel and reports to the tailings.<ref name = "Neiman"/> These tailings are typically retreated in a scavenging operation to try to recover some of the remaining bitumen.<ref name = "Neiman"/>
Three industrial-size single downcomer Jameson Cells were sold by Xstrata Technology to [[Shell Canada]] in 2007 for a large scale pilot plant project and eight 500 mm downcomers were sold to [[Syncrude|Syncrude Limited]] in 2008.<ref name = "Installations"/> In the latter case, the downcomers were used to treat middlings in an existing tertiary oil recovery vessel in a bitumen recovery process patented by Syncrude.<ref name = "Neiman"/>
===The Mark IV Cell (2009– )===
====Mark IV improvements==== [[File:Jameson Cell downcomer quick-release clamps.png|thumbnail|Figure 10. Photograph of the quick-release clamps used to attach the slurry line to the top of the Jameson Cell downcomer.]]
The Mark IV Cell design was introduced in 2009. It included the following improvements: * a flexible hose for easier alignment of the downcomer * clamping of the slurry lens onto the downcomer (see Figure 10) * stainless steel quick-release clamps in the downcomer assembly * long-lasting rubber flaps in the AISE valves.<ref name = "Osborne"/>
==Current applications==
===Base and precious metals flotation===
In base and precious metals flotation, the Jameson Cell has established itself as being particularly useful in several applications in flotation circuits that also use other types of flotation cells, such as mechanical cells. These applications include:
* preflotation roughers for removing naturally hydrophobic gangue materials<ref name = "XT">Xstrata Technology, [http://www.jamesoncell.com/EN/Downloads/Documents/brochure_en.pdf Jameson Cell brochure.] Accessed 2 July 2013.</ref> (such as carbon, talc and elemental sulfur), where the Jameson Cell minimises the entrainment of the valuable minerals while eliminating naturally floating gangue minerals that would otherwise contaminate the concentrate<ref name = "Smith">T Smith, D Lin, B Lacouture and G Anderson, [http://www.jamesoncell.com/EN/Downloads/technical%20papers/Removal%20of%20Organic%20Carbon%20with%20a%20Jameson%20Cell%20at%20R.pdf "Removal of organic carbon with a Jameson Cell at Red Dog mine,"] in: ''Proceedings of the 40th Annual Meeting of the Canadian Mineral Processors, Ottawa, Ontario, 22–24 January 2008'' (Canadian Institute of Mining, Metallurgy and Petroleum), 333–346.</ref><ref name = "Carr">D Carr, G Harbort and V Lawson, "Expansion of the Mount Isa Mines copper concentrator phase one cleaner circuit expansion," in: ''Eighth Mill Operators' Conference, Townsville, Queensland, 21–23 July 2003'' (The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy: Melbourne, 2003), 53–62.</ref><ref name = "Pokrajcic">Z Pokrajcic, G J Harbort, V Lawson and L Reemeyer, "Applications of the Jameson Cell at the head of base metal flotation circuits," in: ''Centenary of Flotation Symposium, Brisbane, Queensland, 6–9 June 2005'' (The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy: Melbourne, 2005), 165–170.</ref> * rougher-scalper and roughing duties where selectivity and froth washing produce high-grade concentrate. In this application, the recovery in one Jameson Cell is normally equivalent to several mechanical cells, and where the feed contains fast-floating liberated particles, the Cell can produce final-grade product, thus reducing the number of mechanical cells required in a flotation circuit<ref name = "XT"/><ref>D Curry, M Cooper, J Rubenstein, T Shouldice and M Young, "The right tools in the right place: how Xstrata Nickel Australasia increased Ni throughput at its Cosmos plant," in: ''Proceedings of the 42nd Annual Meeting of the Canadian Mineral Processors, Ottawa, Ontario, 19–21 January 2010'' (Canadian Institute of Mining, Metallurgy and Petroleum), 215–234.</ref> * cleaner-scalper duties, in which the Jameson Cell recovers fast floating minerals to produce a final-grade concentrate, thus reducing the load on the rest of the cleaning circuit and reducing its size.<ref name = "Barns2009"/><ref name = "XT"/> In this application, it can also be used as a low-cost way of expanding the capacity of an existing cleaner circuit<ref name = "Seaman">D R Seaman, F Burns, B Adamson, B A Seaman and P Manton, "Telfer processing plant upgrade – the implementation of additional cleaning capacity and the regrinding of copper and pyrite concentrates," in: ''11th Mill Operators' Conference 2012, Hobart, Tasmania, 29–31 October 2012'' (The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy: Melbourne, 2012), 373–381.</ref><ref name = "Bennett">D Bennett, I Crnkovic and P Walker, "Recent process developments at the Phu Kham copper–gold concentrator, Laos," in: ''Proceedings of the 11th Mill Operators' Conference, Hobart, Tasmania, 29–31 October 2012'' (The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy: Melbourne, 2012), 257–272.</ref> * final cleaning duties where mechanical cleaning circuits are unable to consistently produce final grade concentrate because of entrained gangue, the Jameson Cell with its enhanced selectivity and froth washing, is able to remove the gangue<ref name = "XT"/><ref name = "Lauder">D W Lauder, M Mavotoi and J W Glatthaar, "Fluorine removal from OK Tedi copper/gold concentrates," in: ''Eighth Mill Operators' Conference, Townsville, Queensland, 21–23 July 2003'' (The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy: Melbourne, 2003), 203–209.</ref>
===Coal flotation===
The Jameson Cell has been found to be particularly effective in cleaning and recovering fine coal particles. For example, at BHP Coal's Goonyella mine (now part of the BHP Mitsubishi Alliance) eight Cells were installed to replace the entire 32 mechanical cell flotation circuit in 1995 in its 1800 t/h coal flotation plant.<ref name = "Osborne"/><ref name = "Carretta"/> The result was an overall increase in yield for the plant of 3.5% (better than the predicted yield of 2.1% that was used to justify the project) and the production of a low-ash product.<ref name = "Carretta"/>
Since then, Jameson Cells have been installed in many coal preparation plants around the world,<ref name = "Installations"/> with the largest installation at the [[Curragh coal mine]] in Australia, where 12 Cells treat over 5 million t/y of coal fines.<ref name = "XT"/>
The Cell can also be applied to coal preparation plant tailings to recover fine coal previously discarded.
===SX–EW plants===
The Jameson Cell is used to recover the organic solvent in solvent extraction – electrowinning plants from both the electrolyte and [[raffinate]] streams.<ref name = "XT"/>
Contamination of the electrolyte increases operating costs and reduces the quality of the copper product.<ref name = "XT"/> Any solvent remaining in the raffinate stream represents a loss of solvent and hence an increase in operating costs.<ref name = "XT"/>
Major users of the Cell in SX–EW plants include Freeport McMoRan at its Morenci operations, BHP Billiton at its [[Olympic Dam mine|Olympic Dam]] operations and Grupo México at its Cananea and La Caridad operations.<ref name = "Installations"/> In all, Xstrata Technology reports 41 SX–EW applications.<ref name = "Installations"/>
Recent developments in the Cell design for SX–EW applications include large, flat-bottomed cell design to allow it to sit on the ground and large (500 mm diameter) downcomers that can have multiple liquor (there being no slurry in SX–EW applications) lenses fitted to each downcomer.
The biggest operating Cell is at the Olympic Dam operations, treating 3000 m<sup>3</sup>/h of raffinate.<ref name = "XT"/>
===Potash===
The first potash application was in England in 1993, where Jameson Cells were used to treat potash slimes (see [[Jameson Cell#Potash flotation|Potash flotation]]).<ref name = "Burns"/> It has subsequently been applied at Israel Chemicals Limited's Dead Sea Works and by an unnamed producer in the Saskatchewan province of Canada.<ref name = "Installations"/>
===Oil sands=== The Jameson Cell has been adopted by Shell Canada and Syncrude for floating bitumen in the oil sands industry (see [[Jameson Cell#Bitumen flotation|Bitumen flotation]]).<ref name = "Installations"/> Syncrude bought an additional eight 500 mm downcomers for its plant in 2012.<ref name = "Installations"/>
===Iron ore===
The Jameson Cell can be used for the reverse flotation of silica from iron ore, where flotation columns have traditionally been used.<ref name = "LH"/>
===Phosphate flotation===
Phosphate processing operations that use flotation as the principal mechanism to concentrate the phosphate-bearing minerals usually discard particles smaller than 20 µm in diameter.<ref name = "Teague"/> This is because the fine particles have had poor flotation performance and because their presence decreases the flotation performance of the coarse particles.<ref name = "Teague"/>
Legend International Holdings Incorporated ("Legend") owns major phosphate deposits that average 20–60% particles less than 20 µm that contain up to 50% of the phosphate.<ref name = "Teague"/> This makes the traditional phosphate concentration practice uneconomic for these deposits.<ref name = "Teague"/> In response, Legend developed a process based on using the Jameson Cell in a rougher-scavenger-cleaner configuration to recover at least 80% of the phosphate at a grade of at least 32% P<sub>2></sub>O<sub>5</sub> from a feed with a particle size distribution of up to 80% less than 20 µm.<ref name = "Teague"/>
==Advantages ==
The Jameson Cell reportedly has the following advantages: * ''relatively low energy use'' – the only energy that is required to operate the Cell is to pump the slurry through the slurry lens. This means that it requires significantly less electricity than conventional mechanical or column flotation cells.<ref name = "Young2013"/> In addition, the better particle–bubble contact means that fewer Cells are required for the equivalent duty of mechanical cells, giving an even bigger power saving.<ref name = "Harbort1997"/> * ''high recovery of fines'' – The Cell is able to achieve final product specification from previously discarded coal fines at very high recoveries (95–98%) in a single pass.<ref name = "Young2013"/> It has also been shown to be effective in recovering fine particles in base metals, potash and phosphate applications. * ''effective froth washing'' – The Cell uses froth washing as standard to control concentrate grade. A conventional flotation cell has problems with recovering fine particles at high grades due to the entrainment of gangue minerals in the froth.<ref name = "Araya"/> The high throughput of the Jameson Cell means that the froth is produced in a small surface area so it is economic to apply froth washing to all cells<ref name = "Seaman"/> * ''easily scaled up'' – the hydrodynamic conditions for particle collection inside the downcomer and separation in the tank are identical between the laboratory, pilot plant and industrial-scale Jameson Cell, meaning that there is direct scale-up. This makes predicting plant performance for small-scale tests straightforward.<ref>Xstrata Technology, [http://www.jamesoncell.com/EN/JamesonCellAdvantages/Pages/AccurateDesignandScaleUp.aspx "Accurate design and scale-up."] Accessed 9 June 2013.</ref> In contrast, factors have to be used to scale-up the design of mechanical and column flotation cells. * ''relatively small footprint'' – the high intensity of bubble-particle contact means that very low residence times are required in the Cell (residence time in the downcomer is 5–10 seconds<ref name = "Atkinson"/> and the separation tank volume is small compared with alternative technologies<ref name = "Barns2009"/>). This means that the total volume of the Cell is lower than the alternatives. * ''fast response to process changes'' – process variables such as air flow rate, froth depth and wash water are all automated making optimisation straightforward.<ref>Xstrata Technology, [http://www.jamesoncell.com/EN/JamesonCellAdvantages/Pages/EasytoTune.aspx "Easy to tune – quick to respond."] Accessed 1 July 2013.</ref> The small tank volumes means very short residence times in the tank (typically 1–3 minutes) so changes made, whether they are deliberate or from normal plant fluctuations, are observed almost instantly. * ''rapid start-up and shutdown'' – the small volume of the tank means that the Cell can be filled and drained quickly so with plant upsets the Cell can reach steady state very quickly. * ''low maintenance costs'' – the Cell has no moving parts and is designed to provide easy access to serviceable parts. The slurry lens orifice has a service life exceeding 5 years under normal operating conditions and the service life of the other wet-end wear parts is reported to be over 10 years under normal operating conditions.<ref>Xstrata Technology, [http://www.jamesoncell.com/EN/JamesonCellAdvantages/Pages/MinimalMaintenance.aspx "Minimal Maintenance – High Availability."] Accessed 7 June 2013.</ref> * ''low capital cost''<ref name = "Carretta"/> – the small footprint of the Cell reduces the amount of steel required in its construction and, coupled with the simplicity of its design, has lower installation costs when compared with conventional or column flotation cells. * ''low operating costs'' – the lack of moving parts with a consequent lower power consumption, long wear life and easy access results in low operating costs. * ''short payback periods'' – Cell users typically report short payback periods for their investments in the technology. For example, the 2007 installation of a 5.4 m diameter Jameson Cell with 18 downcomers to treat preflotation concentrate recovered up to 90% of the zinc previously lost to the tailings disposal facility and had a payback of approximately one year at the zinc prices of the day.<ref name = "Smith"/> Peko Mines reported a payback period of two months for its Cell installation.<ref name = "Jameson1991"/> The complete replacement of 32 mechanical cells with eight Jameson Cells at the Goonyella coal mine had a payback of 17 months.<ref name = "Carretta"/> More recently, the installation of a Cell ahead of each of two cleaner trains at the [[Telfer Mine]] had a payback of between two and seven months.<ref name = "Seaman"/>

{{Infobox person | name = Leonid Mikhelson | birth_name = Leonid Viktorovich Mikhelson | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1955|8|11|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Kaspiysk]], [[Russian SFSR]] | image = Leonid Mikhelson.jpg | caption = Mikhelson in 2016 | alma_mater = [[Kuibyshev Civil Engineering Institute]] | occupation = CEO, chairman and major shareholder of the Russian gas company [[Novatek]] | net worth = US$19.7 billion (August 2018)<ref name="forbes.com">{{cite web |title=Forbes profile: Leonid Mikhelson |url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/leonid-mikhelson/ |website=Forbes |accessdate=1 July 2018}}</ref> | residence = [[Moscow]], Russia | spouse = Married | children = 2 }}
'''Leonid Viktorovich Mikhelson''' ({{lang-ru|Леонид Викторович Михельсон}}; born 11 August 1955) is a Russian [[billionaire]] businessman, CEO, chairman and major shareholder of the Russian gas company [[Novatek]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.novatek.ru/eng/about/managementbios/ |title=NOVATEK : Management |publisher=Novatek.ru |date=2010-12-31 |accessdate=2011-03-16}}</ref> Novatek is subject to US sanctions.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/05/world/paradise-papers.html|title=Paradise Papers Shine Light on Where the Elite Keep Their Money |author=Michael Forsythe |date=November 5, 2017 |website= |publisher= |access-date=8 March 2018 |}}</ref>
According to Forbes, his personal fortune was estimated at US$18.2 billion as of 2017.<ref name="forbes.com"/>
==Biography== Born to a [[Russian Jews|Jewish]] family,<ref>[http://www.jpost.com/Jewish-World/Jewish-Features/The-worlds-50-Richest-Jews-31-40 The world's 50 Richest Jews: 31-40] By JERUSALEM POST STAFF, 09/07/2010</ref> Mikhelson began his career as an engineer after<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://sibur.com/about/controls/directors/person50/|title = Leonid Mikhelson - Chairman of the Board of Directors|date = |accessdate = |website = Sibur.com|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> graduating with a degree in [[Industrial Civil Engineering]] from the [[Samara Institute of Civil Engineering]] in 1977. He started working as a<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://history.caspianenergy.net/enperson/info/89|title = Leonid Viktorovich Mikhelson|date = |accessdate = |website = Caspian Energy|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> foreman at a construction and assembling company in the [[Tyumen]] area of [[Siberia]]. One of his<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url = http://jewishbusinessnews.com/2014/05/29/leonid-mikhelsons-sibur-buys-25-joint-venture-interest-in-new-siberian-polypropylene-plant/|title = Leonid Mikhelson’s Sibur Buys 25% Joint Venture Interest In New Siberian Polypropylene Plant|date = May 29, 2014|accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> initial projects was work on the Urengoi-Chelyabinsk gas pipeline. In 1985, he was<ref name=":0" /> appointed as Chief Engineer of Ryazantruboprovodstroy. In 1987, he became General Director of Kuibishevtruboprovodstroy. In 1991, Kuibishevtruboprovodstroy was one of the first companies to undergo privatization after the dissolution of the [[Soviet Union]].
Mikhelson continued as Managing Director at the company, which has been renamed NOVA, until October 1994. He then became General Director of its holding company, Novafinivest, which later became known as NOVATEK. From 2008 until 2010 Mikhelson was Chairman of the Board of Directors for OAO [[Stroytransgas]] and OOO Art Finance. He currently holds the position of Chairman of the Board of Directors of ZAO [[Sibur|SIBUR]] and serves on the Supervisory Board of OAO Russian Regional Development Bank.
SIBUR is a gas processing and petrochemicals company operating 26 production sites across Russia with headquarters in [[Moscow]]. Mikhelson owns 57.5% interest in Sibur. He also holds a 25% stake in Novatek.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/christopherhelman/2015/05/06/novateks-leonid-viktorovich-mikhelson-surviving-russias-turmoil/#3dadaf8d63b2|title=Novatek's Leonid Mikhelson: Surviving Russia's Turmoil|last=Helman|first=Christopher|work=Forbes|access-date=2017-06-15}}</ref>
He also owns the megayacht Pacific.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.superyachtfan.com/superyacht/superyacht_pacific.html|title=[Leonid Mikhelson]: Inside his Crazy US$ 150,000,000 Yacht PACIFIC|first=Peter|last=Yachtfan|website=www.superyachtfan.com|accessdate=1 July 2018}}</ref>
Mikhelson has a strong interest in art, stating that “99 per cent” of his interest is in Russian and contemporary art.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/cae2ece2-be3f-11e2-9b27-00144feab7de?mhq5j=e1|title=Laying the foundations|last=|first=|date=|website=Financial Times|access-date=}}</ref> He also established his own foundation, the [[V-A-C Foundation]], which promotes contemporary Russian art, and has international ties with the New Museum in New York, the Tate museums in the UK , and London’s Whitechapel gallery.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.artnet.com/art-world/v-a-c-foundation-leonid-mikhelson-ne-site-540011|title=Moscow's V-A-C Foundation's Local and Global Reach - artnet News|date=2016-07-05|work=artnet News|access-date=2017-06-15|language=en-US}}</ref> In May 2017, the foundation also opened an exhibition space in Venice and work is underway to develop V-A-C's first major art centre in Moscow, whose main site is an historic power station on the banks of the Moskva River. Designed by Renzo Piano Building Workshop, the new centre for contemporary arts and culture in Moscow is due to open in 2019.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://theartnewspaper.com/news/museums/russian-billionaire-s-v-a-c-foundation-opens-space-in-venice/|title=Russian billionaire’s V-A-C Foundation opens space in Venice|last=|first=|date=|website=theartnewspaper.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170510163258/http://theartnewspaper.com/news/museums/russian-billionaire-s-v-a-c-foundation-opens-space-in-venice/|archive-date=2017-05-10|dead-url=yes|access-date=}}</ref>
== Notable Partnerships == Mikhelson often partners with Russian billionaire [[Gennady Timchenko]]<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.forbes.com/profile/gennady-timchenko/|title = Gennady Timchenko|date = |accessdate = |website = Forbes|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> on business and investment projects. They are partners and majority shareholders in Novatek and Sibur. In 2013, Mikhelson and Timchenko sold 12% of Sibur to management partners. Both Mikhelson and Timchenko appear on the [[Forbes]] list of billionaires.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.forbes.com/billionaires/|title = The World's Billionaires|date = |accessdate = |website = Forbes|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> In 2012, Mikhelson was listed as the second-richest Russian<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://richestrussian.com/1-100/leonid-mikhelson/|title = Leonid Mikhelson|date = |accessdate = |website = Richest Russian|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> in a number of articles including Bloomberg.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-08-21/billionaire-mikhelson-becomes-russia-s-second-richest-man.html|title = Billionaire Mikhelson Becomes Russia’s Second-Richest Man|date = August 22, 2012|accessdate = |website = Bloomberg Business|publisher = |last = Shiryaevskaya|first = Anna}}</ref> Mikhelson and Novatek are the main sponsors of the [[Russian Football Union]].
Mikhelson is the recipient of the Russian Federation’s Order of the Badge of Honor.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.themoscowtimes.com/business/article/novatek-to-sponsor-russian-football-union/488777.html|title = Novatek to Sponsor Russian Football Union|date = October 31, 2013|accessdate = |website = The Moscow Times|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Global/Issues/2013/11/04/Marketing-and-Sponsorship/Novatek.aspx|title = Natural Gas Company Novatek Takes Over Sponsorship Of Russian Football Union|date = November 4, 2013|accessdate = |website = Sports Business|publisher = |last = Kozlov|first = Vladimir}}</ref>
==Personal life== Mikhelson is married, with two children, and lives in Moscow.<ref name="forbes.com"/> His daughter Victoria studied art history at [[New York University]] and London's [[Courtauld Institute]].<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2017/mar/13/future-sounds-of-russia-geometry-of-now-festival-ges2-moscow-leonid-mikhelson|title=Prawn sex … and other future sounds of Russia|first=Alex|last=Needham|date=13 March 2017|website=the Guardian|accessdate=1 July 2018}}</ref> His VAC Foundation Victoria, the Art of Being Contemporary, is named after her.<ref name="auto"/>

{{Infobox person | image = MediaCorp CEO Lucas Chow 20110126.jpg | image_size = | name = Lucas Chow Wing Keung | caption = Lucas Chow speaking at the movie premiere of [[It's a Great, Great World]] | birth_date = {{Birth based on age as of date|58|2012|9|3}} <ref name="sbr" /> | birth_place = Hong Kong | nationality= Singaporean<ref name="Edge" /> | alma_mater = [[University of Aston]] | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = [[Chairperson|Chairman]], [[Health Promotion Board]] | salary = | networth = | spouse = | website = | children = }} '''Lucas Chow Wing Keung''', better known as '''Lucas Chow''' is the former [[Chief Executive Officer]] of [[MediaCorp]], [[SingTel Mobile]].<ref name="Singtel">{{cite news |url=http://www.telecompaper.com/news/lucas-chow-leaves-singtel |title=Lucas Chow leaves SingTel |publisher=telecompaper.com |accessdate=2012-07-20}}</ref> and Group Chief Executive Officer and Managing Director of [[Far East Orchard]].
He is currently the Chairman of [[Health Promotion Board]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Health Promotion Board|url=http://app.sgdi.gov.sg/listing.asp?agency_subtype=dept&agency_id=0000000877|publisher=Health Promotion Board|accessdate=20 July 2012}}</ref> and a member of the Board of Trustees of [[National University of Singapore]]<ref name="NUS">{{cite web|title=NUS Board of Trustees|url=http://www.nus.edu.sg/annualreport/2011/trustees1.html|publisher=National University Singapore|accessdate=20 July 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130105180154/http://www.nus.edu.sg/annualreport/2011/trustees1.html|archivedate=5 January 2013|df=}}</ref>
==Early life== Chow was born in Hong Kong and subsequently granted Singapore citizenship.<ref name="Edge">{{cite news|last=Ho|first=Frankie|title=The Far East Re-organization|newspaper=The Edge Singapore|date=20 June 2012|pages=18–20}}</ref> He graduated with a Bachelor of Science (Honours) degree from the University of Aston, United Kingdom.<ref name="NUS" />
==Career== Chow started his career at [[Hewlett-Packard]] where he worked for over 20 years and eventually becoming the company's head in Singapore.<ref name="Edge" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Far East Orchard Group CEO Lucas Chow to retire|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/business/singapore/far-east-orchard-group/1174690.html|publisher=Channel NewsAsia|accessdate=20 June 2014}}</ref>
He joined SingTel in May 1998 and was subsequently appointed Chief Executive Officer of SingTel Mobile. In July 2000, he was appointed Executive Vice-President of Consumer Business and responsible for the fixed-line, multimedia and mobile communications services. He assumed the position of Executive Vice-President of Corporate Business in April 2004, looking after the telecommunications needs of corporate customers.<ref name="Singtel" />
He joined MediaCorp in 2005. During his tenure at Mediacorp, he served as the chairman of [[Smart Alliance]], a regional broadcasters’ association, to cooperate along three areas — content, sales and marketing, and technology — and capitalise on the economies of scale and combined market that the region can offer.<ref name="Mediacorp">{{cite news |url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/1110877/1/.html |title=CEO Lucas Chow resigns from MediaCorp |publisher=[[MediaCorp Channel NewsAsia|Channel NewsAsia]] |accessdate=2012-07-20}}</ref>
He relinquished his position as CEO of MediaCorp in July 2011.<ref name="Mediacorp" /> and assuming the post of Executive Director at [[Far East Organization]] (FEO).<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/1111330/1/.html |title=Far East Organization appoints Mr Lucas Chow as Executive Director |publisher=[[MediaCorp Channel NewsAsia|Channel NewsAsia]] |accessdate=2012-07-20}}</ref>
On March 2012, Chow was appointed the CEO of [[Far East Orchard]] (previously known as ''Orchard Parade Holdings''), a subsidiary of FEO.<ref name="sbr">{{cite news |url=http://sbr.com.sg/hotels-tourism/people/orchard-parade-holdings-appoints-lucas-chow-wing-keung-ceo |title=Lucas Chow appointed CEO of Orchard Parade Holdings |publisher=Singapore Business Review |accessdate=2012-07-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporebusinessnews/view/1187801/1/.html |title=Lucas Chow appointed CEO of Orchard Parade Holdings |publisher=[[MediaCorp Channel NewsAsia|Channel NewsAsia]] |accessdate=2012-07-20}}</ref> He was re-designated as Group Chief Executive Officer and Managing Director on July 12, 2012.
In June 2014, FEO announced that Chow will retire on September 1, 2014.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fareast.com.sg/feo%20ca/Press_Releases/20140618-media-release.pdf |title=Press Release |publisher=Far East Orchard |accessdate=2015-08-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924010552/http://www.fareast.com.sg/feo%20ca/Press_Releases/20140618-media-release.pdf |archivedate=2015-09-24 |df= }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
